author: Novelty
title: Rock and Roll
review: This set doesn't have the chrome drill, but it makes up for it by having that huge black scoop at the front and the big bubble tyres.  The vehicle is designed nicely with a working hoe and it is asthetically pleasing.  The set comes with the brown monster thing (which makes this the smallest set with the monster) and the ubiquitious 2-piece hollow rock with the neon-yellow crystal inside that's the standard gimmick for this theme.

author: mrmitch
title: Beware of the dreaded ROCK MONSTER
review: When I got back into LEGO's, Rock Raiders was one of the first themes we embraced. Like this set for the big bucket on the front, easy to build, fun to play with, and Rock Monster keeps those workers on thier toes.

author: zinkk757
title: 5/5 good set
review: i like this set because of the rock monster and just about everything.  the set uses bulky parts that actually go ok together but still bug me a little.  i let it slide though and just forget it.  the figure is cool and i like the loader lifting mechanism.  nothing much is wrong with it and it's a good set to purchase.

author: Ovid07
title: Cool Digger.
review:
Lately I've been trying to beef-up my reviews.  Please give me feed back with the "did you find this helpful" rating system, if you find a review of use. -Ovid07 (David)

INTRO
This is another set from the so-so rock raider line-up.  Along with #4980 (tunnel transport) it's one of the only good sets.

LOOKS
This set obviously looks well enough like a digger, however how Lego used the big piece at the bottom I don't like much.  I mean come on Lego!, this is obviously a new mold and will probably never be used again (or in any of my Mocs for that matter)!  If you want to take a close look at this piece go to a part scan on PICSL, and prepare to be amazed.

SIZE IN RELATIONS WITH COPPERATE MARKETING.
This is a small yet beautiful set.

FEATURES
The main drawing point for this set is the movible bucket.  Lego achivees this by ataching a chain pice to the bucket, and the handle thingy on the back.  This works fine , however I would rather see some technic pices (fuss, fuss).

OVERALL      
Despite a few draw backs this set is worth $10.00-$15.00 today on ebay or bricklink.  Why it so good get two. :)

author: deluckybrick
title: This set ROCKS!
review:
This set is one of the best ones that I had got from Rock Raiders. It has many features:

Pros:
-Cool shovel piece
-Very nice base of wheels
-Large wheels
-Brickonium
-The rock monster
-Boulder
-Tools
-Innovative construction

Cons:
-None come to mind!

Very good set, deserves a nine because nothing's perfect.

author: smiley905
title: they rock monster is awsome
review: i love the rock monster, though he could be more posable. the trucks lifting thingy works great and when you pull it it lifts up the rock. the cab is grat and has more than enough room for the guy and his tools. the boulder is good and has a neet crystle in it. the wheels and boddy is extremely usefull for building other big veicles. i dont like the guy hes kinda weird looking, but his helmet is cool. it comes with lots of tools and dynamight, and the rock giant is cool!!

author: dragon_teenager
title: A decent Rock Raiders machine
review:
I love Rock Raiders, and this is a pretty good example of the theme. It's got a powerful, industrial, gritty look to it and comes with a great minifig. However, it is probably the most juniorized of the theme and the bucket lift mechanism isn't the greatest. 

= PROS = 

- Solid construction. This set is built like a rock. No pun intended.

- Some good pieces- cool accessories and a rare brown chain. 

- Great minifig.

- Includes rare Rock Monster. This one of the two sets this figure appeared in. The other was the big Rock Raiders HQ, which was obviously a far more expensive method of obtaining the monster.

- Pretty fun to play with. 

- Good display.

 
= CONS = 

- Rather juniorized. 

- The bucket lift gimmick isn't really the greatest, as the locks tend to fall off. 

- Some unslightly gaps plague the model, however it's still very solidly built. 

- I wish it had included somebody besides Axel, since he appeared in many other sets. 


All in all a decent set, definitely for you if you like Rock Raiders and don't mind large pieces. It's pretty cheap on Ebay, too. However, if you want a really good example of Rock Raiders, the Tunnel Transport is by far the best set in the theme and I would recommend that over this.

author: Blade
title: Digging Made Easy!
review:
This set is one of my favourite sets. It is from he short lived Rock Raiders series that started in 1999 and died out at the turn of the millennium, which is a shame as it had some great models and was made into an excellent computer game. 

The Loader-Dozer is one of the four larger vehicles and has a lot of great features. The shape of the chassis was unique to the series only being used in this set and the Chrome Crusher back in the day and more recently in 05 in the XXL Mobile Crane but in a different colour. 

The bucket on the dozer is pretty big and can hold a few blocks. The best part of this is the bucket is on a chain attached to a leaver at the back to vary the hight and angle of the bucket. The lever can be locked into place to hold the bucket up when it has a big load.

The other great things about the model are the wheels and the cockpit. The wheels are quite large and very able to handle any terrain. The cockpit has has a full cage to protect him and is on hinges for easy playability. The vehicle is controlled by computer system, which makes it more futuristic. The vehicle is also equiped with moveable headlights and tools like a pipe wrench, spanner and dynamite.

The mini-fig is named Alex. He is the main driver in the rock raider series. He is wearing grey pants, black shirt with overalls, brown helmet and  neon yellow face shield. His face is half smile half smirk with orange hair and black sideburns.

The other two things that come with this set and really up the playability are the rock monster, which is one solid piece but his arm moves a full 360 degrees and a boulder, which splits in half to reveal a neon green energy crystal. The first releases came with a comic book, which I have one and is really neat.

Overall this is a brilliant model that I can find no fault with, other than it's not still in stores. The playability is quite high and the aesthetics are really high in my book. I feel this model is a 9/10 as it is really good but not quite perfect. I would recommend this model to anyone who likes space, fantisy, adventure or just a nice model o add to your collection.

author: hustla187
title: Another Great Rock Raiders Set
review: This is one of my favorite sets of the Rock Raiders theme because you get a Rock Monster which are rare now, a boulder, Axle, and the Loader Dozer. I like the Loader Dozer because the wheels are cool, the scooper is way ahead of its time, and has alot of colored pieces not seen any where else. This is such a great set that it should be rereleased.

author: Rgijaba
title: its a nice rock raiders large veicle ready to clear rubble and bring ore to the tool store!
review: this set comes with axle, a rock  monster (paint one blue to get a ice monster) an ore and a green energy crystle.i like how you can make the scoop go up and down.it also comes with diamite, so you can blast through hard rock!

author: Brock_the_Builder
title: Tough Lookin' Set
review:
This set looks great when built.  It says, "don't mess with me."  It is sturdy when built, and I'm a big fan of the large plastic wheels since they roll so nice (remember the Solar Snooper?).  It has a working bucket on the front which is linked the rear via a plastic chain-- its main feature.  The colors are cool, and the set is easy to build.

If I had 1 complaint, it would be that the set is almost too easy.  It uses a lot of large, bulky parts which make it not challenging  to build.  When complete, it almost feels more like a fisher-price toy than a lego.  

Even so, it is still one of the better Rock Raiders sets (along with HQ and Granite Grinder).  If you can find it in good shape, for cheap, get it.

author: Ben_r_l
title: Don't mess with Axle
review: As the Rock Raiders star driver, axle really looks the part in this mean machine, The scoop at the front is incredible and the wheels will get the dozer past any obstacle in it's path But look out, the rock monkey included isn't going to give that crystal up in a hurry! A great set well worth the money, provides many hours of quality playtime, no complaints from me!

author: krysto2002
title: A great set for any fan
review:
This set has great playability, especially with the rock monster included (though it could have used a better pose), and is great for any construction, space, or Rock Raiders fan.

The set is mid sized, has plenty of tools, and one minifigure (any more would be overcrowded). The Loader Dozer has a positionable bucket, which makes it stay up even when weighed down. The cockpit is raised higher the vehicle, giving it an "out of harm's way" feel, especially with that Rock Monster (which is surprisingly rare!). The vehicle has a large base with large wheels, making it good for harsh terrain, plus the base adds playability since it serves good for any vehicle, especially large ones!

The set is kind of alkwardly built but is just fine the way it is. At $20 it was a pretty good deal, especially since the next set up with a Rock Monster is $100!

author: WiseWarrior
title: My favorite Rock Raiders set
review:
This set has it all: A big vehicle, (complet with lots of cool features like the scooping bucket and a unique cockpit), the every-awesome Rock Monster, and a boulder with a crystal inside.

Overall a must-have, buy it off a site like bricklink, since it's no longer available in stores.

author: KLOKRIECHER
title: LEGO Rock Raiders - The Loader-Dozer Review
review:
This is a cheap way to get a LEGO rock monster of the LEGO Rock Raiders theme if you can't buy the Rock Raider HQ set. This set comes with some nice parts which look really rare like the roll cage which we get on the top of the cockpit. The inside of the cockpit is really nice. We get a nice printed screen. I also like the way how LEGO did designed the shovel which you can lift up. The minifig which we get is called Axel. As I told you in my Granite Grinder review on brickset.com I think there're way too many sets with this character.

This set also comes with a rock piece which you can open to see the crystal. I really missed that rock in the LEGO Power Miners theme. Also the rock monster is very cool. The whole monster is just one piece. The legs and the head don't move but the arm does. I think that LEGO should have produced the monsters from the videogame in this set because they look more evil than that creature. But I really have to complain much about this set.

All in all this set is a great set and I would recommend you to get this. You can find this set on eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure. Here is the link where you can check out the full gallery I made for this set on my website: http://www.klokriecher.de


Videos I made of this set:

Stopmotion 2
Stopmotion 3
Stopmotion 4
Review

author: SirSceptile
title: Scoop the Rubble Without any Trouble!
review:
A great Rock Raiders set! Bigger than the piece count suggests, plus a cheaper alternative to get the ever elusive rock monster (only other way is RR HQ)

Pros

  • ROCK MONSTER!
  • Nice design with higher cockpit
  • Brown Chain
  • Dynamite
  • Rare wrench pieces
  • Interesting bucket mechanism
  • Bucket fits 2 rocks
  • Fun to play with

Cons

  • Axel again...

Some people say this set is juniorized, but that isn't really the case, yes a few of the pieces are bigger, but it is still an awesome set.

A great buy for anyone who likes RR and a very fun set to have!

author: AETerry
title: Rock Raider Dozer Review
review:
A Rock Raiders set from the late 1990's, this set features a rare rock monster figure. Also of note is that one of the accessories is a monkey wrench that I hadn't seen since Fabuland sets.

 

The Dozer itself is fairly solid with huge wheels for moving over rocky terrain and a big scoop for large boulders. The cockpit is a bit clunky by today's standards of Lego, but it was pretty cool then. As usual, this set like others in the Rock Raiders theme has a good color theme going for it.

author: Harmonious_Building
title: Low-down loader.
review:
The Rock Raiders came out towards the end of my age-appropriate enthusiasm for LEGO (does such a concept exist?), and, even now, I feel largely ambivalent towards the Rock Raiders line as a whole. I think I warmed up to it slightly in later years (as evidenced by the fact that I have a surprising number of sets from the theme; honestly I don’t even remember how/why I got them all - perhaps I was intoxicated on BrickLink one night or something - but, on the whole, the Rock Raiders designs just seemed to be somewhat lacking in terms of overall coherence and aesthetic.

That isn’t to say that the concept isn’t inherent cool. Although Hollow-Earth Theory has taken a blow in recent years thanks to David Icke, there is something fascinating about a (post apocalyptic?) culture existing beneath the surface of the planet. Sure, they’re ostensibly digging for crystals or something like that, but who cares? You have massive, manly machines that exude power and plough through stuff. 

That being said, it doesn’t seem as though Loader-Dozer should have any major failings. It’s an enormous sci-fi-ish bulldozer that comes with huge wheels and a simple mechanism for operating the bulldozer piece in the front. A polyhedronic (probably not a word, but I don’t care) cockpit with a matching cover (lacking in a certain practical usefulness against overhead rubble that may fall on top of the machine) provides ample room for the sole Minifig to operate his bulldozer, and a handful of specialised tools allow him to get any small jobs done. And that Rock Monster! Is there anyone who doesn’t love it? (I no longer have my Rock Raiders sets on display, but my Rock Monsters have found a happy home in antagonising my Fantasy Era Dwarves.) 

But perhaps it’s precisely the brutishness of the Loader-Dozer that ultimately contributes to its lack of aesthetic. A low piececount is a direct result of enormous, highly-specialised pieces, many of which are listed in the preceding paragraph. All of this gives the set a rather “juniorised” feel, which is not really a word that one wants to associate with a set about manly men drilling into the core of the Earth. Other than the Rock Monster, it’s a little hard to find things to love about this set. 

I suppose that credit should be given to LEGO for attempting to break into a new non-space sci-fi subgenre a la Aquazone, but Rock Raiders doesn’t quite seem to make the mark, and Loader-Dozer unfortunately exemplifies that, in my opinion. In fact, I was sort of shocked the discover, ten years later, that the Rock Raiders found themselves revived in the form of the Power Miners, which are even weirder. I guess there must be a market for this somewhere.

author: Constructionbricks
title: 89-piece beast!
review:
I missed out on Rock Raiders, being born in the 2000’s, but thankfully, I was able to get one of these on BrickLink in 2015, for less than $20. I played with it for hours upon hours as a set, scooping up Lego bricks an other toys, as well as playing in the dirt outside, mining up Brickonuim crystals and battling rock monsters! I also took it apart and used its pieces on countless numbers of creations! I have so many fond memories of this set, and it has become one of my all-time favorites!

Box/Instructions

I do not have the box, but I heard it has the same picture as the instructions; the Loader Dozer in action, and the rock monster attacking it, taking a crystal. The instructions are easy to follow, but do have one mistake. A light grey 1x2 piece is printed red in one part, but it doesn’t affect the building experience. Both the box and instructions have pictures of alternate models that can be built with the set’s pieces, to get your creativity started. One is a transport hovercraft, another is a digger/hovercraft vehicle, and the third (only on the box), is a wheeled vehicle with some sort of chomping/crushing mouth. Man, I miss the days when Lego used to encourage creativity this way! The set also included a mini comic book with a hilarious story in it (all of the 1999 Rock Raiders sets did; each one had a different story).

Minifigs/Accessories

 The set includes one mini-figure named Axel. He has a black shirt, grey overalls, binoculars hanging around his neck, grey pants, and a black belt. His face has no beard, but he does have black sideburns, orange hair, and a smiley face. He has a brown helmet with a yellow-green visor. The set also includes a rock monster, which looks very stony and has a movable right arm. He can hold crystals and throw bricks. His feet can attach to bricks and baseplates. Unfortunately, he is not very articulated, as his right arm is the only thing that moves.

The set also has 2 wrenches, probably for repairs, dynamite (printed on a 1x2 tile), for blasting rocks or fighting rock monsters, a boulder (ore) and a Brickonium energy crystal. The boulder splits apart to reveal the crystal.

Honestly, this may just be me, but I almost think it should have had just one wrench and a different tool, like a pick axe or jackhammer. No biggie though.

Parts

While this set may not have in the way of pieces, whet it does have makes up for it. This set contains some of the rarest and most useful pieces in my collection. The big bucket is my favorite part, and is featured in many Technic sets. Sometimes, when building MOC’s, I would make a huge grabber claw out of two of them. The chassis is one huge piece, which makes the build relatively simple but nonetheless, is very useful. I have used it in many creations, and I also have the 4970 Chrome Crusher, so I have 2 of these chassis pieces! Many times, I have combined the two to make giant 8-wheeled vehicles. The monstrous tires are cool, and the cockpit is made of two pieces: the bottom half and the brown cage, which are two very rare pieces. I have used the bottom piece on makeshift boat hull creations before. There are also lots of regular bricks, plates, and tiles in a variety of colors, some of which are rare. Notable examples include the turquoise 1x2 grill tiles and the sloped brick. There are also several transparent neon-yellow/green pieces, which I always thought were cool! Last but not least is the rare brown chain!

The build

Containing only 89 pieces, most of them being large, the set took only about 5 minutes to build, but at the time, I was glad because I couldn’t wait to play with it. You basically start with the big chassis and build up from there.

The completed model

The Loader Dozer is a beast when built! It is quite large for an 89 piece set, mostly due to the large pieces. It has a huge bucket at the front for scooping rocks and dirt up. You move it up and down with a handle at the back which is hooked to a brown chain which pulls the bucket up and down. The bucket can hold 2 boulders or a few Lego bricks. It can be locked into place when carrying loads, thanks to a simple but ingenious locking mechanism. The monstrous tires roll very smoothly. It looks as if it could drive over very rough terrain with those tires. The roll cage over the cockpit opens so you can put a mini-figure operator inside, and close it to protect the operator from falling rocks or rollovers. There are two headlights to illuminate the underground caverns. Inside there is a seat and computers to control it. Admittedly, the cockpit is less detailed than in some of the other Rock Raiders sets. There are 2 clips for storing the wrenches (or other tools).

The only flaws are that some parts, like the headlights, tool clips, and even the handle used to operate the bucket pop off sometimes, and the rock monster isn’t very articulated. The cockpit could be a little bit more detailed, but that is very minor, and don’t forget, you can always add details yourself!

Value for money

The retail price seems a little high for the part count, but the rare and useful pieces, and the impressive model make up for it, so I think it is worth the money! You can sometimes find it cheaper that the original price when used.

Overall opinion

Overall, this set, while relatively basic, is nonetheless phenomenal! It provides hours of fun play, looks good on a shelf, and includes some rare and useful pieces; not to mention the highly sought after ROCK MONSTER!!! It definitely proves that a set does not have to be complex in order to be cool! If you can find one for sale, I advise you, buy it, especially if you like Rock Raiders!

 

Thanks for reading and God bless!
